questions.text: Which of the following operates based on a negative feedback mechanism? Thyroid hormone regulation Blood glucose regulation Blood clotting cascade Nerve Signal Propagation Temperature regulation
questions.explanation:
System

Stimulus

Response

Effect

Body Temperature

Temperature deviation

Sweating/shivering, vasodilation/constriction

Restores normal temperature

Blood Glucose

High/low blood glucose

Insulin/glucagon release

Normalises blood glucose levels

Thyroid Hormones

High/low thyroid hormones

TSH release adjustment

Maintains hormone balance

Blood Pressure

High/low blood pressure

Heart rate and vessel adjustment

Restores normal blood pressure

Calcium Homeostasis

High/low blood calcium

PTH/calcitonin release

Normalises blood calcium levels

Menstrual Cycle

Hormone level changes

FSH/LH regulation

Regulates menstrual cycle

Respiratory Rate

High CO2 levels

Increased breathing rate

Normalizes CO2 levels

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of transcellular fluid?

options.label: A
options.text: Cerebrospinal fluid

options.label: B
options.text: Peritoneal fluid

options.label: C
options.text: Vitreous humor

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Fluid in the lumen of structures lined by epithelium.

Examples
  • Fluid in the secretion of exocrine digestive glands
  • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
  • Pleural, peritoneal, synovial and pericardial fluids
  • Intraocular (aqueous and vitreous humor) fluids
  • Bile
  • Luminal fluids of the gut
  • Fluid in the cochlea and kidney tubules

Volume

  • 1.5% of body weight
  • About 1L.

questions.text: Which statements about the cell membrane are correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Sphingolipids form channels for water and water-soluble substances, aiding diffusion.

options.label: B
options.text: Cholesterol acts as a receptor for peptide hormones, triggering intracellular processes.

options.label: C
options.text: Peripheral proteins penetrate the lipid bilayer and actively transport substances.

options.label: D
options.text: Glycocalyx contributes to negative surface charge, cell adhesion, and immune reactions.

questions.correct_answer: D. Glycocalyx contributes to negative surface charge, cell adhesion, and immune reactions.
questions.explanation:
Component

Description

Function

Phospholipids
  • Most abundant
  • Arranged in a bilayer with hydrophilic heads outward and hydrophobic tails inward.
  • A barrier to water-soluble substances, allowing fat-soluble substances to pass.

Sphingolipids
  • It is found in smaller amounts, especially in nerve cells.
  • Protection
  • Signal transmission
  • Adhesion sites for extracellular proteins

Cholesterol
  • Embedded in the lipid bilayer.
  • Influences membrane permeability and fluidity

Type

Description

Function

Integral Proteins

Span the entire lipid bilayer, protruding on both sides.
  • Transport: Form channels for water and ions.
  • Selective Diffusion: Facilitate specific substance diffusion
  • Carrier Proteins: Bind and transport substances, including active transport
  • Enzymes: Catalyze reactions
  • Receptors: Bind ligands to trigger intracellular processes

Peripheral Proteins

Attached to the inner or outer surface, not spanning the lipid bilayer.
  • Function as enzymes or regulators of substance transport.

Component

Description

Function

Glycoproteins

Proteins with carbohydrate chains
  • Protection
  • Cell recognition
  • Signaling.

Glycolipids

Lipids with carbohydrate chains
  • Cell recognition
  • Communication.

Proteoglycans

Carbohydrate-rich compounds that are attached to the outer cell surface
  • Structural support
  • Interaction with the extracellular matrix.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches a junction type with its key features?

options.label: A
options.text: Tight Junctions - Provide mechanical strength and link cytoskeletons of adjacent cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Adherens Junctions - Create a seal between adjacent cells and prevent the passage of molecules through intercellular space.

options.label: C
options.text: Desmosomes - Form channels between cells, allowing direct passage of small molecules and ions.

options.label: D
options.text: Gap Junctions - Enable rapid communication and coordination, forming channels between cells for electrical signal propagation.

questions.correct_answer: D. Gap Junctions - Enable rapid communication and coordination, forming channels between cells for electrical signal propagation.
questions.explanation:
Mechanism

Key Components

Physical Contact
  • Tight junctions
  • Adherens junctions
  • Desmosomes
  • Gap junctions

Chemical Messengers
  • Hormones
  • Neurotransmitters growth factors

ECM Interaction
  • Proteins polysaccharides

Type

Key Features

Tight Junctions
  • Create a seal between adjacent cells.
  • Prevent the passage of molecules through intercellular space.
  • It is essential for maintaining tissue barriers and regulating substance movement across epithelia.

Adherens Junctions
  • Provide mechanical strength.
  • Link cytoskeletons of adjacent cells.

Desmosomes
  • Similar to adherens junctions in function.
  • Provide additional mechanical stability.

Gap Junctions
  • Form channels between cells.
  • Allow direct passage of small molecules and ions.
  • Enable rapid communication and coordination (e.g.- electrical signals in cardiac muscle).

Type

Role

Integrins
  • Cell-to-cell and cell-to-ECM adhesion
  • Involved in cell signaling, migration, and proliferation

Immunoglobulins
  • Cell-to-cell adhesion
  • Immune recognition

Cadherins
  • Calcium-dependent
  • Mediate cell-to-cell adhesion
  • Crucial in tissue morphogenesis

Selectins
  • Transient cell-to-cell adhesion in the bloodstream
  • Enable white blood cells to bind to endothelial cells and migrate to inflammation sites

questions.text: Which of the following is considered downhill transport?

options.label: A
options.text: Active transport

options.label: B
options.text: Passive transport

options.label: C
options.text: Primary active transport

options.label: D
options.text: Secondary active transport

questions.explanation:
Passive Transport

Active Transport

Primary Active Transport

Secondary Active Transport

Moves molecules down their gradient (downhill transport) from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration

 

 

Moves molecules against their gradient (uphill transport) from an area of lower concentration to an area of higher concentration.

 

 

It uses ATP directly to move molecules against their gradient from an area of lower concentration to an area of higher concentration.

 

It uses energy from the gradient created by primary active transport

 

Primary active transport creates an ion gradient (e.g., Na+ gradient by the Na+/K+ pump)

↓

Na+/K+ pump uses ATP to pump Na+ out of the cell (against its gradient)

↓

A high concentration of Na+ outside the cell

↓

Uses the Na+ gradient to transport other molecules (e.g., glucose) into the cell

It does not require energy

Requires energy (ATP)

Requires energy (ATP)

Energy is indirectly required from the ATP used by the Na+/K+ pump

Example: Diffusion of oxygen (O2) across a cell membrane

Example: Sodium-potassium pump (Na+/K+ pump)

Example: Calcium pump (Ca2+ pump)

Example: Glucose-sodium co-transport (SGLT)

Downhill transport

Not downhill transport

Not downhill transport

Not downhill transport

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Na⁺-K⁺ ATPase is false?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an electrogenic pump with a coupling ratio of 3Na+:2K+

options.label: B
options.text: The α subunit has intracellular Na⁺ and ATP-binding sites

options.label: C
options.text: The α subunit contains the phosphorylation site at Asp 376

options.label: D
options.text: Its activity is enhanced by ouabain and digitalis glycosides

questions.correct_answer: D. Its activity is enhanced by ouabain and digitalis glycosides

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding facilitated diffusion is false?

options.label: A
options.text: It does not require ATP expenditure.

options.label: B
options.text: Involved transport protein is stereospecific and follows saturation kinetics.

options.label: C
options.text: Diffusion of ammonia in collecting ducts is a type of facilitated diffusion.

options.label: D
options.text: Molecules move down the chemical gradient from high to low concentration.

questions.correct_answer: C. Diffusion of ammonia in collecting ducts is a type of facilitated diffusion.

questions.text: Select the correct statements regarding endocytosis:

options.label: A
options.text: Pinocytosis involves ingesting solid particles into the cell by budding small vesicles from the cell membrane.

options.label: B
options.text: Phagocytosis is a type of endocytosis that involves the ingestion of liquid into the cell.

options.label: C
options.text: Receptor-mediated endocytosis is a non-selective process where molecules are ingested into the cell without needing receptors..

options.label: D
options.text: All forms of endocytosis require ATP for the vesicle formation process

questions.correct_answer: D. All forms of endocytosis require ATP for the vesicle formation process
questions.explanation:
Pinocytosis
(Option: A)
  • Referred to as "cell drinking".
  • Uptake of extracellular fluids by budding small vesicles from the cell membrane.

Phagocytosis
(Option: B)
  • Referred to as "cell eating".
  • Engulfs large particles such as pathogens or cellular debris. into the cell.

Receptor-mediated endocytosis

(Option: C)
  • Specific molecules are ingested into the cell by binding to specific receptors on the cell surface.
  • Clathrin-mediated endocytosis:
    • Triskelion shape protein (3 heavy and 3 light chains).
    • Presents on the surface of the cell membrane
    • Provides a coating on the surface of the vesicle with the help of dynamin protein.

questions.text: Oxygen moves from the alveoli into the blood across the alveolar-capillary membrane. Which of the following best describes this process?

options.label: A
options.text: Facilitated Diffusion

options.label: B
options.text: Simple Diffusion

options.label: C
options.text: Non-ionic diffusion

options.label: D
options.text: Osmosis

questions.explanation:
Simple diffusion

Facilitated diffusion (Option A)
  • Move from high to low solute concentration (downhill transport)
  • It does not require energy.
  • Not require carrier protein (channel protein may or may not be present)
  • No saturation: more concentration leads to a higher rate of transport.
  • Fick's law: Rate (J) = D.A.∆C/x
    • D: Diffusion constant.
    • A: Surface area of diffusion.
    • X: Thickness of the membrane.
    • ∆C: Concentration difference between membranes (most important determinant).
  • Movement of molecules across a membrane via carrier protein.
  • No expenditure of energy.
  • For example, glucose is transported by all types of GLUT.
  • Saturation is achieved after a certain point called the plateau.
  • The maximum transport rate occurs at the plateau or saturation point, called maximum (Tm)

questions.text: Which of the following is likely to be seen if a patient is infused with 3% NaCl?

options.label: A
options.text: Water shifts from ICF to ECF

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased plasma protein concentration

options.label: C
options.text: Increased arterial blood pressure

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

questions.explanation:
Disorder

Examples

Effects

Hyperosmatic Volume Expansion
  • Excessive infusion of hypertonic saline.
  • Increase in ECF volume.
  • Increased plasma osmolality
  • Water shifts from ICF to ECF
  • Decreased plasma protein concentration
  • Increased arterial blood pressure

Hyposmotic Volume Expansion
  • SIADH
  • Increase in ECF volume.
  • Increase in ICF volume.
  • Decrease in plasma osmolarity.
  • No change in hematocrit.
  • Decreased plasma protein concentration.

Isosmotic Volume Expansion
  • Infusion of isotonic NaCl
  • Increase in ECF volume.
  • No change in ICF volume.
  • No change in osmolarity.
  • Decreased hematocrit.
  • Decreased plasma protein concentration.
